messageBody:
I think you want to encapsulate the call to the API that your tests use only once. Although it is usually wise to set up each individually test and this is why setUp and tearDown are so handy.

However, it you really want to re-use an object throughout your tests create them in the constructor. The class that your tests are in will only be instantiated ONCE by the test framework. Therefore, if you want to create an object X once and re-use it in all your tests you can do something like this:

class YourTests extends TestCase
{
public YourTests(String name)
{
super(name);
// YOUR SET UP CODE HERE
TheObjectYouWantToReUse X = new TheObjectYouWantToReUse();
}


public void testXXX()
{

}
}

James Dobson

I believe that is normal, with or without extending: setUp and
tearDown get called for every test method. Makes sense conceptually
if you think about it: each method is an entire test unto itself, and
so needs its own setup.
